critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their tail as a warning signal, flashing the white underside to alert others.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to urban areas, often thriving near cities by scavenging food and hunting small animals.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm in cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are excellent climbers, one of the few North American canines that can climb trees!

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high to catch prey or escape danger.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupinesâ€™ quills are modified hairs coated with thick keratin to defend against predators.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers can hold their breath underwater for up to 15 minutes while building their dams!

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build waterproof lodges from mud and vegetation to stay safe and warm in water.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming underwater.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and use trees to hunt prey like squirrels and birds.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to stay dry while swimming and hunting!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find food buried under a foot of snow using their excellent memory!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches, storing thousands of seeds for winter survival.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks use cheek pouches to carry food back to their burrows for storage and winter use!

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color from brown in summer to white in winter for camouflage.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have incredibly sensitive front paws, helping them identify objects even in complete darkness!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums can eat venomous snakes without getting sick, thanks to their immune system!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a stinky liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and hunt insects in complete darkness.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats can live over 19 years, using echolocation to hunt insects at night!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls say â€œWho cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?â€ to communicate with mates.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow or nerves!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where females can also sing beautifully to defend their territory.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their winter food stash!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice often mimic other birdsâ€™ calls to protect their territory from intruders.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can walk headfirst down tree trunks, unlike most birds that only go upward!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects and communicate with other woodpeckers nearby.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers have longer beaks than Downy Woodpeckers, helping them reach deep insect tunnels.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create loud drumming sounds by chiseling deep rectangular holes in trees for insects.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum loudly to mark territory and attract mates using their strong beaks.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 mph, making them surprisingly fast fliers!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, showing bright yellow summer feathers and duller winter plumage.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called â€œsnowbirdsâ€ because they appear in winter across much of North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are one of the few bird species where males have red feathers from their diet!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches eat seeds and berries and can sing up to 20 different song variations!

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can fly up to 55 miles per hour despite their large size!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a unique drumming sound by beating air with their wings to communicate.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes dance to attract mates, showing off impressive moves like bowing and jumping!

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows are highly intelligent and can recognize human faces, remembering friends and foes alike.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech, showcasing impressive intelligence and vocal skills!

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their incredible sharp vision.

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks use surprise and agility to hunt birds through dense trees in forests and suburbs.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are one of the few duck species with colorful, iridescent feathers on both males and females!

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, using a distinctive V-shaped formation to save energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for minutes, patiently waiting to catch fish with their sharp beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can live over 30 years and have powerful jaws to catch prey quickly!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can rapidly change color to communicate and protect their territory during breeding season.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth Bass can grow over 20 inches long and use their big mouths to catch prey!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, helping them blend into underwater plants!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and have sharp teeth to catch slippery fish!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can jump over 3 feet in a single leap to catch their prey!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can live both in water and on land, making them excellent amphibious swimmers!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length in a single leap!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and are often found near water, catching fish and amphibians to eat!

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 20 minutes while searching for food!

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous snakes with their colorful patterns to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to find warm climates during winter.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies use their colorful tail-like wings to confuse predators and escape attacks easily.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, left, and right!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings over their bodies, unlike dragonflies that hold wings open while resting.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use light signals to attract mates, creating beautiful natural light shows at night!

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of food with their hive mates!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature by vibrating their flight muscles to stay warm in cold weather!

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their body length using their powerful hind legs!
